title: Water well charity founded by Tasmanian woman changing lives in Africa
text:
Photo: Catherine Wheatley with an Ethiopian villager. (Supplied: Water For A Village) 
Catherine Wheatley installed her first hand-dug well in remote Ethiopia three years ago, and she has now raised over $70,000, and transformed 12 villages. 
Ms Wheatley fell in love with the World Heritage listed Simien Mountains National Park in northern Ethiopia three years ago, on a two-week hiking adventure. 
"I was really shocked and horrified by the amount of poverty in that region, people have absolutely nothing," she said. 
"There's no roads, no money, no jobs, no sanitation, no electricity and there's definitely no water." Building a well Hole dug at least 5m deep Concrete cylinders cast, lowered into place Surface platform, livestock fence built Pump put in place 
The United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund (UNICEF) has stated an estimated 42 million people in Ethiopia do not have access to safe water. 
Ms Wheatley said she witnessed villagers sharing puddles of water with baboons, donkeys and other farm animals, and women and children spending most of their day carrying water on their backs to their homes. 
With a PhD in bio-chemistry, it was something the Hobart woman, who grew up on a farm near Campbell Town, could not ignore. 
"I just couldn't turn my back on it, so we put our first well in and started our organisation because people were so interested in it." Ms Wheatley said.
